proxyLocation: mounted in the upper half of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Stand in front of the TV and tap or push the center of the glass screen with the flat of your index finger. Although the surface itself does not travel, the hard, immovable plane can still convey the instant impact moment of the virtual button press; after contacting the screen, quickly pull your finger back 4 cm to self-simulate the travel stroke and rebound.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This virtual button would be used for triggering critical actions
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The red cap responds to downward pressure by traveling vertically into the base assembly. The travel distance is about 4cm. Users should feel progressive compression resistance.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: The raised profile of the button above the base should provide obvious targeting feedback, with clean edges defining the round surface area.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will approach the button with a direct downward press, typically using the pad of the index finger or the flat of the palm for dramatic effect. The motion is a short, piston-like thrust: wrist remains mostly neutral while elbow and shoulder supply a quick 4–6 cm travel. Contact is concentrated at the center of the circular cap. As force increases, the cap offers progressive spring resistance, then bottoms out against an internal stop before immediately rebounding when released. Haptically, the user expects a firm initial resistance, a smooth compression over the 4 cm stroke, a soft mechanical 'click' or detent at full travel, and a rapid return to the starting height.

physicalObject: dual-disc metal lamp head on a stand
proxyLocation: left side of the wooden surface in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Place your index finger on the upper disc’s center hole and press downward. The disc assembly tilts slightly on its pivot and the perforated metal flexes a few millimetres, offering light resistance. Follow through by pushing 4 cm toward the lower disc, using your arm to generate the perceived travel before releasing; the lamp head’s slight spring back mimics the rebound.

proxyLocation: mounted at the back of the desk, occupying the top half of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: With the television turned OFF, let the user glide open fingertips across the cool, perfectly smooth glass. The uninterrupted surface allows long, slow strokes that recreate the gentle hand-to-leaf contact; the light friction of glass on skin delivers continuous tactile feedback similar to sliding over broad, flat leaves.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This potted plant would be used for gentle, therapeutic interaction. VR players would run their hands along the leaves for stress relief.
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The leaves function as flexible, responsive plant material that bends and flexes naturally as hands pass over them. Users should feel the leaves gently deflecting under their touch.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: The leaf surfaces should convey slightly coarse plant skin with subtle raised veining patterns running through each leaf.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users interact with the plant in a gentle, exploratory manner, grazing fingertips or an open hand across the foliage. Movements are slow strokes or light taps, fingers slightly spread to let leaves slip between them. Contact focuses on finger pads and sometimes the dorsal side of the hand as users scoop upward from pot rim to leaf tips. The leaves flex away, providing low-force, compliant resistance (<0.5 N), then spring back once the hand passes. Users perceive slight textural variations—the faint ridges of veins—while overall softness conveys living plant material.

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The leaves function as flexible, responsive plant material that bends and flexes naturally as hands pass over them. Users should feel the leaves gently deflecting under their touch.
virtualObjectInfo.texture: The leaf surfaces should convey slightly coarse plant skin with subtle raised veining patterns running through each leaf.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users interact with the plant in a gentle, exploratory manner, grazing fingertips or an open hand across the foliage. Movements are slow strokes or light taps, fingers slightly spread to let leaves slip between them. Contact focuses on finger pads and sometimes the dorsal side of the hand as users scoop upward from pot rim to leaf tips. The leaves flex away, providing low-force, compliant resistance (<0.5 N), then spring back once the hand passes. Users perceive slight textural variations—the faint ridges of veins—while overall softness conveys living plant material.

proxyLocation: top half of Snapshot 1, hanging above the wooden surface
utilizationMethod: Use the wide, smooth bezel as a low-friction surface: place the side of your hand or two fingers on the glossy frame and execute a continuous sideways swipe. The long uninterrupted glide mimics giving a tangential push to a globe and conveys the feel of an object that keeps moving after the initial force.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This desktop globe would be used for educational exploration in classroom. VR players would rotate the sphere to navigate around the world.
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The globe functions as a rotating mechanism that responds to touch with smooth, controlled spinning around its vertical axis.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The globe invites a tangential push or drag gesture. A user typically places one or two fingertips or the side of the hand on the sphere and applies a sweeping arc motion horizontally, initiating rotation about the fixed vertical axis. Larger motions might use the whole palm, with wrist pronation/supination controlling spin speed. The sphere responds with smooth, low-friction inertia—initial force overcomes static friction, after which it glides freely, gradually decelerating due to mild bearing resistance. Users may also steady the globe by lightly pinching the meridian ring while the opposite hand spins the sphere.

rawResponse:
[
  {
    "virtualObject": "Soccer",
    "physicalObject": "large black flat-screen television",
    "object_id": 1,
    "image_id": 0,
    "proxyLocation": "fixed vertically above the wooden surface, front glass panel",
    "utilizationMethod": "Stand about one foot away and give a very light toe tap to the lower bezel or glass. The absolutely rigid, non-yielding surface conveys an unmistakable rebound impulse at the moment of contact, helping the user time the brief impact phase of a soccer ki

proxyLocation: standing vertically at the back of the desk, snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Use the narrow lower bezel as a rigid horizontal bar. Run fingertips along the flat edge and tap it rhythmically; each tap mimics striking a piano key while the continuous bar keeps spatial orientation for glissandos.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Musical performance. VR players would press the piano keys to generate musical notes.
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The keys function as pressure-sensitive switches that depress smoothly when pressed and spring back immediately upon release. Users should feel distinct key travel distance with clear actuation points.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should perceive an organized array of keys arranged layout. The linear arrangement of keys should provide clear spatial reference points
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users perform rapid, repeated finger presses on the linear key array. Each key is targeted with an isolated finger—thumbs for lower keys, remaining digits for mid/high—while wrists float slightly above the board. A key press involves a 1–1.5 cm downward travel, encountering a smooth initial glide, a definitive actuation point halfway, and a cushioned bottom. Release relies on the key’s spring, returning the finger to the neutral position for the next note. Chords require simultaneous multi-finger depression, and glissandos generate continuous fingertip slides across sequential keys, each key momentarily depressing under the moving finger.

physicalObject: silver dual-disc metal lamp head on black stand
proxyLocation: left side of the wooden surface, snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Rest the fingers on the upper disc and perform short downward presses against the springy swivel joint of the lamp head. The slight give of the hinge gives a tactile ‘travel’ similar to a key press.

proxyLocation: near center-bottom of the desk, snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the metal arms and repeatedly squeeze the clip open with fingertips. The arms provide discrete resistance and snap-back similar to a key’s actuation and return, suitable for practicing single rapid presses.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Musical performance. VR players would press the piano keys to generate musical notes.
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The keys function as pressure-sensitive switches that depress smoothly when pressed and spring back immediately upon release. Users should feel distinct key travel distance with clear actuation points.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should perceive an organized array of keys arranged layout. The linear arrangement of keys should provide clear spatial reference points
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users perform rapid, repeated finger presses on the linear key array. Each key is targeted with an isolated finger—thumbs for lower keys, remaining digits for mid/high—while wrists float slightly above the board. A key press involves a 1–1.5 cm downward travel, encountering a smooth initial glide, a definitive actuation point halfway, and a cushioned bottom. Release relies on the key’s spring, returning the finger to the neutral position for the next note. Chords require simultaneous multi-finger depression, and glissandos generate continuous fingertip slides across sequential keys, each key momentarily depressing under the moving finger.

proxyLocation: front right of the desk, snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Invert the cup so its open end faces the desk. Press the base downward with a finger; the thin plastic flexes a few millimeters then rebounds, supplying a shallow travel analogous to a soft piano key.
